statement: A 16-cell lithium-ion battery pack with trapezoidal configuration and 5-inlet, 1-outlet setup achieves balanced thermal performance under varying airflow speeds.

quantitative.conditions: lower bound of tested airflow speeds

statement: A 16-cell lithium-ion battery pack with trapezoidal configuration and 5-inlet, 1-outlet setup achieves balanced thermal performance under varying airflow speeds.

quantitative.conditions: upper bound of tested airflow speeds

statement: The integration of phase change materials (PCMs) in a 16-cell lithium-ion battery pack stabilizes thermal behavior.
A comprehensive 3D simulation approach can be used to analyze thermal performance of lithium-ion battery packs.
Compact designs and varying airflow conditions in drone applications present unique thermal management challenges for lithium-ion battery packs.
Designing efficient cooling strategies tailored to lightweight applications such as drones and portable energy storage systems is an area for future research.
The authors perform phase-field simulations of electrodeposition in metal-anode batteries with anisotropic representation
A modified lithium crystal surface anisotropy representation is proposed for phase-field electrodeposition model
The proposed formulation exhibits low sensitivity to numerical parameters
Change of dendritic morphological behaviour is captured by simulating variations of the inter-electrode distance
Simulations show agreement with experimentally-observed lithium dendrite growth rates and morphologies
Lithium dendrite growth rates and morphologies are well-established in the literature
Dendrite formation during electrodeposition compromises the safety of lithium metal batteries
High shear modulus solid-ion conductors have been prioritized to resolve pressure-driven instabilities
SICs can be designed within a universal chemomechanical paradigm to access either pressure-driven dendrite-blocking or density-driven dendrite-suppressing properties
The universal chemomechanical paradigm reveals a dichotomy between pressure-driven and density-driven dendrite formation
Synchrotron hard x-ray microtomography is used to reveal uniform Li plating mediated by SICs
Li plating mediated by SICs with low Li+ partial molar volume is uniform
SICs with atypically low Li+ partial molar volume can be designed to be concomitantly soft
20 percent of the Li inventory is reversibly cycled

quantitative.conditions: thin Li anodes, high-voltage NMC-622 cathodes

statement: Lithium-ion batteries can exhibit rapid, nonlinear degradation that severely limits battery lifetime
Prior work on knees in lithium-ion battery aging trajectories is reviewed
Three classes of internal state trajectories can cause a knee, including snowball, hidden, and threshold trajectories
Six knee pathways are identified, including lithium plating, electrode saturation, resistance growth, electrolyte and additive depletion, percolation-limited connectivity, and mechanical deformation
Some knee pathways have internal state trajectories with signals that are electrochemically undetectable
Key design and usage sensitivities for knees are identified
Challenges and opportunities for knee modeling and prediction are discussed
Lithium-ion battery degradation is complex and subtle
Atomic and molecular layered coatings can substantially reduce dendritic growth in aqueous zinc-ion batteries
Hetero-epitaxial residual stresses due to layered coatings can provide shielding to suppress dendrite formation
Residual stresses due to coatings can reduce chemical potential polarization around dendrite embryos
The deposition of zinc is forced into regions adjacent to protuberances due to residual stresses
The rate of dendritic growth is slower due to the effect of residual stresses
Dendrite suppression is achieved through the effect of residual stresses due to coatings
The fundamental understanding of residual stresses due to coatings can be extended to various metal anode batteries
The approach can be applied to Li or Na batteries
Dendrite formation is a long-standing problem for the commercial application of aqueous zinc-ion batteries
